movies.title: Migrant Dreams
movies.shortDescription: Migrant Dreams follows the story of migrant women from Indonesia who come to work in Ontario greenhouses as part of Canada's Temporary Foreign Worker Program.
movies.longDescription: Migrant Dreams follows the story of migrant workers who come to work in Ontario greenhouses as part of Canada's Temporary Foreign Worker Program.  Many are women recruited by brokers who illegally charge fees upwards of $7,000, with greenhouse owners complicit in the scam.  From award-winning director Min Sook Lee, Migrant Dreams examines the lives of a group of strong, vibrant migrant women who resist systemic oppression and exploitation.

movies.title: Some Sort of Judas
movies.shortDescription: The story of Kevin Williams, a once popular Toronto rapper who became a key witness and informant against his former associate Mark Moore.
movies.longDescription: Some Sort of Judas tells the story of Kevin Williams, a once popular Toronto rapper who became a key witness and informant against his former associate Mark Moore, a violent street thug who shot and killed two innocent men in broad daylight.  Fearing for his life and ostracized by his community for breaking its code of silence, Williams is released from prison into an uncertain future.

movies.title: Inside Kenk
movies.shortDescription: Known as the world's most prolific bicycle thief, Igor Kenk was notorious even before his high-profile arrest in Toronto in 2008. Ten years later in Switzerland, Igor reflects on his past and his new life.
movies.longDescription: Igor Kenk was known as the world's most prolific bicycle thief. His shop in Toronto notoriously sold stolen bikes back to their original owners. In 2008 he was arrested and jailed, after which he sold his shop and disappeared. Ten years later in Switzerland, Igor reflects on his past and his new life. Coarse language. Viewer discretion advised.

movies.title: Picture My Face: The Story of Teenage Head (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: Forty years after sparking the notorious punk rock riot at Ontario Place, legendary Hamilton glamour-punk band Teenage Head is determined to enter the limelight once again.
movies.longDescription: Forty years after sparking the notorious punk rock riot at Ontario Place, legendary Hamilton glamour-punk band Teenage Head is determined to enter the limelight once again.  With the release of a new album and a cross-country tour in the works, founder and lead guitarist, Gord Lewis, battles a crippling depression.  Featuring appearances by Marky Ramone, writers Jon Savage and Nina Antonia (New York Dolls), and rare 16mm colour footage from the 1980 Heatwave Festival. Viewer discretion is advised.

movies.title: Undercover Jihadi
movies.shortDescription: Following international counter-terrorism expert Mubin Shaikh, a former extremist and undercover operative, as he examines efforts to counter violent extremism in Canada, the US and Europe in his quest to stop the radicalization of Muslim youth.
movies.longDescription: Undercover Jihadi follows the quest of Mubin Shaikh, a man who went from extremist militant to undercover operative, to expose a major terrorist cell in Canada and send 11 men to prison.  Today, he's a well-connected international Counter-Terrorism expert and is on a mission to stop the radicalization of Muslim youth. We follow his journey into counter-terrorism in the UK, Canada, the U.S., Germany and France. Led by a personal duty to Islam, Shaikh takes to the frontlines of the battle against the radicalization of youth at risk.

movies.title: Dispatches from a Field Hospital (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: COVID-19 devastated long-term care homes in Ontario. In spring 2020, Windsor erected a field hospital to treat COVID-positive seniors. iPads and phones became lifelines for families, including director Matt Gallagher, whose own father was a patient.
movies.longDescription: The COVID-19 pandemic is devastating long-term care homes across Ontario. During the first wave in the spring of 2020, the city of Windsor erected Canada's first MASH-style field hospital almost overnight to isolate and treat elderly patients from Heron Terrace who tested positive for the virus. To fight back against confusion and despair, medical staff created a lifeline between these seniors and their families using iPads and phones. Dispatches from a Field Hospital documents the dramatic stories of several families, including director Matt Gallagher, whose own father became a patient.

movies.title: Where The Universe Sings (Feature Version)
movies.shortDescription: An intimate portrait of the life and art of Lawren Harris, a founding member of the legendary Group of Seven, and the expansive landscapes that inspired him.
movies.longDescription: An intimate portrait of the life and art of Lawren Harris, a founding member of the legendary Group of Seven, and the expansive landscapes that inspired him.

movies.title: Propaganda: The Art of Selling Lies
movies.shortDescription: Why are we so easily seduced by propaganda?  Propaganda: The Art of Selling Lies traces the history of the art of persuasion from ancient cave art to the present, where we are bombarded by more propaganda than ever before.
movies.longDescription: Why are we so easily seduced by propaganda?  Propaganda: The Art of Selling Lies traces the history of the art of persuasion from ancient cave art to the present, where we are bombarded by more propaganda than ever before. Featuring contemporary artists including Shepard Fairey and Ai Weiwei. Viewer discretion is advised.

movies.title: River Silence (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: The controversial Belo Monte Dam is causing ecological devastation along Brazil's Xingu River, a major tributary of the Amazon and one of the world's most diverse ecosystems. River Silence follows four women whose lives have been profoundly changed.
movies.longDescription: The Belo Monte Dam, one of the world's biggest and most controversial infrastructure projects, is causing massive ecological and social devastation along Brazil's Xingu River, a major tributary of the Amazon that is the lifeblood to one of the world's most diverse ecosystems.  Director Rogerio Soares travels into this mythic and brutalized world to follow four women whose lives and families have been profoundly changed.

movies.title: The Invisible Heart (Feature)
movies.shortDescription: The Invisible Heart tracks the birth of a new financial market that promises to solve society's most complex problems. An unorthodox marriage between capitalism and charity, Social Impact Bonds pay private investors a profit to fund social services.
movies.longDescription: Three centuries after Adam Smith coined the term "the invisible hand", The Invisible Heart tracks the birth of a new financial market that promises to solve society's most complex problems. An unorthodox marriage between capitalism and charity, Social Impact Bonds (SIBs) raise private capital to fund social services.  But what happens when we pay private investors a profit for helping society's most vulnerable?

movies.title: Rescuing Rex (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: When it comes to adopting dogs, millennials lead the pack. With a keen sense of social justice and mastery of social media, they're turning Canada into a haven for the world's homeless dogs.
movies.longDescription: When it comes to adopting dogs, millennials lead the pack. With a keen sense of social justice and mastery of social media, they're saving troubled mutts around the world.  As this new generation comes to the rescue, Canada has become a haven for the world's homeless dogs. Viewer discretion is advised.

movies.title: Prey (feature)
movies.shortDescription: Basilian priest Father Hodgson Marshall was convicted of abusing boys throughout southern Ontario during his decades-long career. Prey follows survivor Rod MacLeod, and his lawyer Rob Talach, as they pursue justice through a public trial.
movies.longDescription: Basilian priest Father Hodgson Marshall was convicted of abusing boys throughout southern Ontario during his decades-long career. Prey follows survivor Rod MacLeod, and his lawyer Rob Talach, as they pursue justice through a public trial in the hopes of forcing the dark and hidden story of clergy sexual abuse to light.  Viewer discretion is advised.

movies.title: Captive (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: Filmed over four years in Nigeria, journalist Mellissa Fung meets several brave young women who have escaped imprisonment by Boko Haram and are now trying to rebuild their lives. Through their struggles, Fung comes to terms with her own past.
movies.longDescription: Captive is a powerful personal journey about surviving the trauma of captivity and the toll conflict takes on women and girls.  Filmed over four years in northeastern Nigeria, Canadian journalist Mellissa Fung meets several brave young women who have escaped imprisonment by Boko Haram and are now trying to rebuild their lives. Through their struggles, Fung comes to terms with her own past, confronting the deep trauma she thought she had long buried. Viewer discretion is advised.

movies.title: Borealis (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: Borealis travels deep into the heart of Canada's iconic wilderness to explore how the plants and animals that live there communicate and survive the destructive forces of fire, insects, and human encroachment.
movies.longDescription: Borealis travels deep into the heart of Canada's iconic wilderness to explore how the plants and animals that live there communicate and survive the destructive forces of fire, insects, and human encroachment.

movies.title: Part One: Dreams & Disasters
movies.shortDescription: Examining the world of Big Gold - from big mines, big markets, and big deals - to big disasters which result in pollution and corruption that powerful players don't want us to see.  Discover what our lust for gold costs, and who pays the price.
movies.longDescription: Examining the world of Big Gold - from big mines, big markets, and big deals - to big disasters which result in pollution and corruption that powerful players don't want us to see. Who wins and who loses?  Discover what our lust for gold costs, and who pays the price.

movies.title: My Millennial Life (Feature Version)
movies.shortDescription: "My Millennial Life" takes a look through the eyes of a group of resourceful, charming and talented 20-somethings and the obstacles and opportunities they face in getting launched and making their mark on the world.
movies.longDescription: Millennials are getting dumped on from all sides - from parents, employers and the economy.  "My Millennial Life" takes a look through the eyes of a group of resourceful, charming and talented 20-somethings and the obstacles and opportunities they face in getting launched and making their mark on the world.  Along the way, there are big dreams, crushing disappointments and the re-imagining of personal identities and the meaning of success.

movies.title: Much Too Young
movies.shortDescription: What does it mean to be a young adult who becomes a caregiver for a parent with early-onset Alzheimer's?
movies.longDescription: What does it mean to be a young adult who becomes a caregiver for an ailing parent? This documentary is a powerful and unflinching look at four families struggling to cope with an unexpected role reversal, and the complications that come with caring for a parent who has been diagnosed with early-onset Alzheimer's disease.

movies.title: Stand Up Toronto
movies.shortDescription: What does it mean to be an up-and-coming, stand-up comedian who isn't white? Stand Up Toronto explores the experience of three comics from diverse cultural backgrounds as they navigate Toronto's stand-up comedy circuit.
movies.longDescription: What does it mean to be an up-and-coming, stand-up comedian who isn't white? Stand Up Toronto explores the experience of three comics from diverse cultural backgrounds as they navigate Toronto's stand-up comedy circuit. As these comics chronicle their attempts to break through in the industry, and break the mold of the comedians who came before them, will they find a place to speak their truth in the complicated world we live in?

movies.title: The Beat Goes On
movies.shortDescription: Members of an innovative music program for older adults rehearse for their year-end concert.
movies.longDescription: The Bloor Street New Horizons Band is the Toronto chapter of an innovative music program for older adults. It's a mixed group composed of members from retired virtuosos to newbies who have never played an instrument before. Over the course of several months, filmmaker Sarah Keenlyside captures the orchestra as they rehearse for their year-end concert. The film serves as a vibrant reminder that creative expression is vital for the soul at any age.

movies.title: The Arrest (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: In Ontario, 44% of those arrested eventually have their charges dropped, but the arrest and judicial process leave many with permanent damage. Toronto lawyer Davin Charney fights for the wrongly charged, demanding justice and compensation.
movies.longDescription: In Ontario, 44% of those arrested eventually have their charges dropped, but the arrest and judicial process leave many with permanent damage. Toronto lawyer Davin Charney fights for the wrongly charged, demanding justice and compensation.

movies.title: Beyond the Spectrum
movies.shortDescription: Two-year-old Oskar is diagnosed with severe autism. His parents decide to drop everything for a year to focus on his therapy.
movies.longDescription: At the age of two, Oskar is diagnosed with severe autism. As he lags further behind his twin sister, his parents decide to drop everything for a year to focus on his therapy. This intimate and affecting portrait follows one family's journey as they wrestle with an impossible question: should they try to change Oskar or accept him as he is?

movies.title: Push (Feature Version)
movies.shortDescription: Housing prices are skyrocketing in cities around the world. Incomes are not. Push sheds light on a new kind of faceless landlord, increasingly unliveable cities, and an escalating housing crisis. Who is being pushed out of the city and why?
movies.longDescription: Housing prices are skyrocketing in cities around the world. Incomes are not. Push sheds light on a new kind of faceless landlord, increasingly unliveable cities, and an escalating housing crisis. The film follows Leilani Farha, the UN Special Rapporteur on Adequate Housing, as she's travelling the globe, trying to understand who's being pushed out of the city and why.

movies.title: Family Camera
movies.shortDescription: A moving look at 150 years of Canadian history through the iconic family photograph. Through the stories of five exceptional Canadian families, Family Camera explores how these images document our lives and bear witness to our history.
movies.longDescription: A moving look at 150 years of Canadian history through the iconic family photograph. From the first photos taken in the 1840s to today's digital snapshots, family photographs have become important historical and anthropological artifacts that collectively reflect who we are as a nation today.  Through the stories of five exceptional Canadian families, Family Camera explores how these images document our lives and bear witness to our history.

movies.title: Running Wild: The Cats of Cornwall (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: Running Wild reveals the staggering impact of outdoor cats on the environment, spotlighting the cat crisis in Cornwall, Ontario and the advocates fighting for humane solutions.
movies.longDescription: Cats might be cute but they are decimating the environment just like other invasive species. As ecologists and activists try to control outdoor cat populations, not everyone is on board. Enter Cornwall, Ontario - a small town with a huge cat problem where advocates are fighting for humane solutions. Finding a fix won't be easy in this small city with a big cat problem.

movies.title: Metamorphosis
movies.shortDescription: With humanity changing the planet's biosphere at an unprecedented scale, climate survivors, scientists, and others explore ecological transformation.
movies.longDescription: Human civilization is changing the biosphere of the planet at an unprecedented scale, leading to species extinction and runaway climate change. This visually stunning film by Nova Ami and Velcrow Ripper features compelling stories from climate survivors, scientists, activists and artists who are responding to this crisis by exploring ecological transformation and asking how humanity will in turn be affected.

movies.title: There Is A House Here
movies.shortDescription: Filmmaker Alan Zweig has been corresponding for years with Tatanniq (Lucie) Idlout, a former rock musician from a legendary Inuit family. Guided by Tatanniq, Alan travels to Nunavut to see what his friend has been telling him about life in the North.
movies.longDescription: Toronto filmmaker Alan Zweig has been corresponding for years with Tatanniq (Lucie) Idlout, a former rock musician who comes from a legendary Inuit family. Guided by Tatanniq, Alan travels to Nunavut to see for himself what his friend has been telling him about life in the North.

movies.title: The Forbidden Reel (Feature Version)
movies.shortDescription: The Forbidden Reel tells the story of Afghanistan's fearless and visionary filmmakers and the Afghan Films Archive, which was nearly destroyed by the Taliban.
movies.longDescription: Driven to create amidst war and chaos, Afghan filmmakers gave birth to an extraordinary national cinema. Driven to destroy, Taliban extremists set out to torch that legacy. Using newly restored images from the Afghan Films Archive, Afghan-Canadian director Ariel Nasr tells the story of Afghanistan's fearless and visionary filmmakers including "Engineer" Latif Ahmadi and Siddiq Barmak.

movies.title: Little India: Village of Dreams
movies.shortDescription: Little India: Village of Dreams explores the vibrant and diverse Toronto neighbourhood known affectionately as "Little India" or the Gerrard India Bazaar, home to a myriad of multi-generational South Asian family businesses.
movies.longDescription: Little India: Village of Dreams explores the vibrant and diverse Toronto neighbourhood known affectionately as "Little India" or the Gerrard India Bazaar. Behind the colourful myriad of restaurants, beauty shops, clothing and grocery stores are the South Asian immigrants and entrepreneurs who founded this community over 40 years ago.  Now, the westernized second generation is adapting their family businesses, reshaping them yet preserving the legacies of their parents for the 21st Century.

movies.title: TRIPPING The Niagara (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: Take a mesmerizing bird's-eye view through southern Ontario's beautiful Niagara region in TRIPPING The Niagara.
movies.longDescription: Take a mesmerizing bird's-eye view through southern Ontario's beautiful Niagara region.  TRIPPING The Niagara starts high above Lake Ontario, flying through the charming streets of Niagara-on-the-Lake, soaring above Fort George, over abundant fruit orchards and vineyards, before dipping deep into the gorge to follow the churning emerald waters of the Niagara River to the world-famous Niagara Falls.

movies.title: Risk Factor
movies.shortDescription: We all try our best to assess the risk factors that may impact us. Individually and as a society, how we assess risk matters. Filmmaker Bob Lang explores the nature of risk, how it informs our decisions and ultimately shapes our lives.
movies.longDescription: We all try our best to assess the risk factors that may impact us.  Individually and as a society, how we assess risk matters.  Filmmaker Bob Lang embarks on a journey to explore the nature of risk, how it informs the decisions we make, and how it ultimately shapes our lives.

movies.title: Lowdown Tracks
movies.shortDescription: Filmmaker Shelley Saywell and singer and activist Lorraine Segato set out to document the music and stories of those who live on the margins of society and bare their souls through their songs on the streets of Toronto.
movies.longDescription: Inspired by depression-era folk songs, filmmaker Shelley Saywell and singer and activist Lorraine Segato set out to document the music and stories of those who live on the margins of society and bare their souls through their songs on the streets of Toronto. It's a journey that takes us along abandoned tracks, beneath bridges, inside shelters, rooming houses and alleyways, and celebrates the music and survival of those who live on the outside.

movies.title: Part Two: Guns, Dust & Mercury
movies.shortDescription: What are the human and ecological costs of gold mining?  Some of the world's poorest people work under hazardous conditions in tiny mines and muddy streams.  Discover how fair and sustainable gold is possible, if we want it.
movies.longDescription: What are the human and ecological costs of gold mining?  Some of the world's poorest people work under hazardous conditions in tiny mines and muddy streams.  Meet small-scale miners who are exploited by warlords, and betrayed by the collusion of refineries and the retail gold industry.  Discover how fair and sustainable gold is possible, if we want it.

movies.title: Anthropocene: The Human Epoch
movies.shortDescription: Anthropocene: The Human Epoch is a stunning cinematic meditation on humanity's massive reengineering of the planet.
movies.longDescription: A stunning cinematic meditation on humanity's massive reengineering of the planet, Anthropocene: The Human Epoch is the final film in an award-winning trilogy that includes Manufactured Landscapes and Watermark.

movies.title: Coppers (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: With his trademark probing interview style, Alan Zweig turns his lens toward the lives of retired police officers, in a hard-hitting, harrowing, and empathetic look behind the fabled "blue wall".
movies.longDescription: With his trademark probing interview style, Alan Zweig turns his lens toward the lives of retired police officers, in a hard-hitting, harrowing, and empathetic look behind the fabled "blue wall". It's a profession marked by adrenaline and chaos, but also by suicide and marital breakdown. No one leaves the job without a mark, and not everyone bounces back. Viewer discretion is advised.

movies.title: The Fruit Machine
movies.shortDescription: Survivors of a decades-long homosexual witch-hunt recount their personal stories of dedication and betrayal at the hands of the Canadian government.
movies.longDescription: In filmmaker Sarah Fodey's documentary, survivors of a decades-long homosexual witch-hunt recount their personal stories of dedication and betrayal at the hands of the Canadian government. Some softened by age and sadness, others loud and angry, the voices of the former public servants targeted in the purge are now united, and determined.

movies.title: 17 and Life Doesn't Wait (feature version)
movies.shortDescription: Exploring the challenges faced by three teenage girls in their final year of high school. Expectations clash with reality and things don't always go as planned, but these teens are determined to find a place for themselves in the world.
movies.longDescription: 17 and Life Doesn't Wait explores the challenges faced by three teenage girls during their final year of high school. Expectations clash with reality and things don't always go as planned, but these teens are determined to find a place for themselves in the world.

movies.title: Dolphin Man
movies.shortDescription: Dolphin Man examines the extraordinary legacy and complex life story of Jacques Mayol, the first free-diver to reach 100 meters below the sea.
movies.longDescription: Dolphin Man examines the extraordinary legacy and complex life story of Jacques Mayol, the first free-diver to reach 100 meters below the sea.  Beautifully shot, the film seeks to understand what drove Mayol to dive so deep, and uncovers his dark side and what led to his suicide in 2001.

movies.title: Painted Land: In Search of the Group of Seven (Feature)
movies.shortDescription: Following author and wilderness photographer Joanie and Gary McGuffin and art historian Michael Burtch, as they set out to find the actual locations in northern Ontario that inspired the legendary Group Of Seven and their iconic paintings.
movies.longDescription: "Painted Land" follows author and wilderness photographer Joanie and Gary McGuffin and art historian Michael Burtch, as they set out to find the actual locations in northern Ontario that inspired the legendary Group Of Seven and some of their most iconic works of art. The film weaves the iconic paintings and fascinating stories of these artists with the modern day journey, taking viewers through some of Canada's most stunning landscapes.

movies.title: My First 150 Days
movies.shortDescription: My First 150 Days follows the Banico family, newly arrived from the Philippines, and their first 150 days in Toronto, capturing their emotional journey of starting fresh in a new land.
movies.longDescription: The first few months in a new country can be difficult when you're learning a new culture, language, and setting down roots in an unfamiliar place. When she left her rural village in the Philippines for Canada, nearly a decade ago, Melona felt the growing pains of immigration. Now, she is sponsoring her 26-year-old daughter, 24-year-old son, 14-year-old daughter and the grandson of her eldest daughter to come to Canada. My First 150 Days follows the family's first 150 days in Ontario together, capturing their emotional journey of starting fresh in a new land.

series.shortDescription: Two politicians with opposing points of view try to get to know each other as they delve into Canada's most important issues.
series.title: Political Blind Date

episodes.title: Ep 2 - Urban Versus Rural
episodes.shortDescription: Mississauga Mayor Bonnie Crombie and Conservative Party Leader from Saskatchewan Andrew Scheer set out to see what the differences and similarities are between urban and rural voters and their needs.
episodes.longDescription: Mississauga Mayor Bonnie Crombie and Conservative Party Leader from Saskatchewan Andrew Scheer set out to see what the differences and similarities are between urban and rural voters and their needs. What can the Conservatives offer to entice urban voters in 2019?

episodes.title: Ep 3 - Taxes
episodes.shortDescription: Do Liberals tax and spend, while Conservatives cut taxes and services? Liberal MP Wayne Easter thinks tax policies help Canadians prosper, but Conservative MP Lisa Raitt thinks money should be left in people's pockets to spend as they see fit.
episodes.longDescription: The political cliché is that Liberals tax and spend, and Conservatives cut taxes and services. But is it true?  PEI Liberal MP Wayne Easter believes that the tax policies of the Trudeau government are helping Canadians prosper, but Ontario Conservative MP and Deputy Leader Lisa Raitt thinks that money should be left in people's pockets to spend as they see fit.

episodes.title: Ep 1 -  Guns
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto Liberal MP Marco Mendicino debates Alberta Conservative MP Glen Motz about Canada's relationship with guns.  Does Bill-C71 infringe on the rights of law-abiding gun owners, and will it stop illegal guns used in violent crimes?
episodes.longDescription: Toronto Liberal MP Marco Mendicino debates Alberta Conservative MP Glen Motz about Canada's relationship with guns.  Does Bill-C71 infringe on the rights of law-abiding gun owners, and will it stop illegal guns used in violent crimes?

episodes.title: Ep 4 -  Indigenous Rights
episodes.shortDescription: Ojibway Liberal MP, Don Rusnak, squares off with Cree NDP MP, Romeo Saganash, to examine the reality for Indigenous communities in Ontario and Quebec, and what it will take to transform the country's relationship with Indigenous peoples in Canada.
episodes.longDescription: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau vowed to transform the country's relationship with Indigenous peoples in Canada.  But has any progress been made since his election?  Ojibway Liberal MP, Don Rusnak, squares off with Cree NDP MP, Romeo Saganash, to examine the reality for Indigenous communities in Northern Ontario and Quebec.

episodes.title: Ep 5 - The Promise of Multiculturalism
episodes.shortDescription: Vancouver NDP MP Jenny Kwan and Toronto Liberal MP Gary Anandasangaree examine whether the promise of acceptance and opportunities are equal for everyone who arrives in Canada, no matter their origin.
episodes.longDescription: Vancouver NDP MP Jenny Kwan and Toronto Liberal MP Gary Anandasangaree examine whether the promise of acceptance and opportunities are equal for everyone who arrives in Canada, no matter their origin. Viewer discretion is advised.

episodes.title: Ep 2 - Subways
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto City Councillors Jim Karygiannis (Ward 22) and Anthony Peruzza (Ward 7) debate the mass transit needs of Toronto's residents, from the Bloor-Danforth Subway Extension to the Finch West LRT, and the Province's new plan to expand the subway.
episodes.longDescription: Toronto City Councillors Jim Karygiannis (Ward 22) and Anthony Peruzza (Ward 7) debate the mass transit needs of Toronto's residents, from the Bloor-Danforth Subway Extension to the Finch West LRT, and the Province's new plan to expand the subway system.

episodes.title: Ep 6 - Hydro Rates
episodes.shortDescription: Conservative MPP Bill Walker and NDP MPP Peter Tabuns examine the government's plans for hydro rates and energy policy in Ontario, debating the merits of retro-fitted energy-efficient homes, community wind turbines, and nuclear power.
episodes.longDescription: Conservative MPP Bill Walker and NDP MPP Peter Tabuns examine the government's plans for hydro rates and energy policy in Ontario, debating the merits of retro-fitted energy-efficient homes, community wind turbines, and nuclear power. What is the province doing to ensure that Ontarians have access to cost effective and environmentally responsible energy?

episodes.title: Ep 5 - The High Tech Future
episodes.shortDescription: Cambridge Mayor Kathryn McGarry and Conservative MPP Donna Skelly have different views on how to support advanced manufacturing and innovation in Ontario's auto, aerospace and medical sectors. Is it through grants or cutting red tape for businesses?
episodes.longDescription: Cambridge Mayor Kathryn McGarry and Conservative MPP Donna Skelly have different views about how best to support advanced manufacturing and high tech innovation in Ontario's auto, aerospace and medical sectors. Is it through grants and incentives or cutting red tape for businesses?

episodes.title: Ep 3 - The Housing Crisis
episodes.shortDescription: City Councillors Ana Bailao and Stephen Holyday examine Toronto's housing crisis. From multi-residential and laneway housing to rapid densification, these two politicians hold very different views on how to house the city's exploding population.
episodes.longDescription: City Councillors Ana Bailao and Stephen Holyday examine Toronto's housing crisis. From multi-residential and laneway housing to rapid densification, these two politicians hold very different views on how to house the city's exploding population.

episodes.title: Ep 4 - The Food We Eat
episodes.shortDescription: Conservative MPP Randy Pettapiece and Ontario Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner look at how farmers are transforming their operations with technical innovations, and debate what role government should play in supporting large and small scale farms.
episodes.longDescription: With a steady decline in the number of farms in Ontario, Conservative MPP Randy Pettapiece and Ontario Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner look at how farmers are transforming their operations with technical innovations, and debate what role government should play in supporting large and small scale farms.

episodes.title: Ep 1 - City Finances
episodes.shortDescription: Provincial funding cuts have forced the City of Toronto to make some hard choices about its budget shortfall. Budget Chief Gary Crawford believes in finding efficiencies, but City Councillor Shelley Carroll believes that new revenue tools are needed.
episodes.longDescription: After provincial funding cuts, the City of Toronto faces hard choices about how to manage its budget shortfall. Budget Chief Gary Crawford doesn't want to raise taxes or create new ones, and believes in finding efficiencies. City Councillor Shelley Carroll believes that new revenue tools are needed to pay for the city's growth, and takes Gary to New York City to examine how taxes saved that city.

episodes.title: Ep 5 - Religious Symbols
episodes.shortDescription: Liberal MPP Michael Coteau and Coalition Avenir Québec MNA Christopher Skeete debate Québec's controversial Bill 21 which bans the wearing of religious symbols for public servants in positions of authority, including police officers and teachers.
episodes.longDescription: Liberal MPP Michael Coteau and Coalition Avenir Québec MNA Christopher Skeete debate Québec's controversial Bill 21 which bans the wearing of religious symbols in Québec for public servants in positions of authority, including police officers, judges, and teachers.

episodes.title: Ep 6 - Cities and the Environment
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto City Councillor Jennifer McKelvie and Conservative MPP Andrea Khanjin examine how the provincial government and city can work together to address environmental issues like climate change, recycling strategies, and air pollution.
episodes.longDescription: Toronto City Councillor Jennifer McKelvie (Ward 25, Scarborough-Rouge Park) and Conservative MPP Andrea Khanjin (Barrie-Innisfil, Parliamentary Assistant to the Minister of the Environment) examine how the Ontario government and the city of Toronto can work together to address environmental issues like climate change, recycling strategies, and air pollution.

episodes.title: Ep 1- Hallway Medicine
episodes.shortDescription: NDP MPP Sara Singh and Conservative MPP Natalia Kusendova examine how to address the challenges of hospital capacity, bed shortages, and health program cuts in Ontario, pre- and post-COVID-19.
episodes.longDescription: NDP MPP Sara Singh and Conservative MPP Natalia Kusendova examine how to address the challenges of hospital capacity, bed shortages, and health program cuts in Ontario, pre- and post-COVID-19.

episodes.title: Ep 2 - Pipeline Politics
episodes.shortDescription: Green Party MP Elizabeth May takes on Conservative MP Cathy McLeod on the pros and cons of the Trans Mountain Pipeline expansion and its impact on Indigenous and non-Indigenous communities across British Columbia.
episodes.longDescription: Green Party MP Elizabeth May takes on Conservative MP Cathy McLeod on the pros and cons of the Trans Mountain Pipeline expansion and its impact on Indigenous and non-Indigenous communities across British Columbia.

episodes.title: Ep 4 - Migrant Labour
episodes.shortDescription: NDP MPP Taras Natyshak and Conservative MP Dave Epp explore possible solutions to the problems faced by migrant workers in Southwestern Ontario, including COVID-19 outbreaks and living conditions that some critics call inhumane.
episodes.longDescription: NDP MPP Taras Natyshak and Conservative MP Dave Epp explore possible solutions to the problems faced by migrant workers in Southwestern Ontario, including COVID-19 outbreaks and living conditions that some critics call inhumane.

episodes.title: Ep. 6 - Carbon Tax
episodes.shortDescription: Ontario Liberal MPP Arthur Potts and Alberta Conservative MP Shannon Stubbs go head-to-head over Canada's controversial plan for carbon pricing.
episodes.longDescription: Ontario Liberal MPP Arthur Potts and Alberta Conservative MP Shannon Stubbs go head-to-head over Canada's controversial plan for carbon pricing.

episodes.title: Ep. 5 - Housing
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto city councillor Maria Augimeri and Liberal MP Adam Vaughan look at creative solutions to find homes for people in need.
episodes.longDescription: Toronto is facing a major housing shortage and a backlog in its social housing repairs. City councillor Maria Augimeri and Liberal MP Adam Vaughan tackle the social housing crisis and look at creative solutions to find homes for people in need.

episodes.title: Ep. 1 - Weeds
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto Liberal MP Nathaniel Erskine-Smith wants all drugs decriminalized, but Alberta Conservative Garnett Genuis is an avowed drug prohibitionist.
episodes.longDescription: This episode brings together two young, first-time MPs: Toronto Liberal Nathaniel Erskine-Smith, who wants all drugs decriminalized, and Conservative Garnett Genuis, an avowed drug prohibitionist from Edmonton. Can an admitted pot smoker and a dedicated scotch lover come to see the implications of their personal choices?

episodes.title: Ep. 4 - Corrections
episodes.shortDescription: NDP MPP Cheri Dinovo and Liberal MPP, Marie-France Lalonde agree that the Corrections Act of Ontario is out-of-date.  Can a life-long champion of the downtrodden move the Minister to see what needs to be done to help those at risk in our prisons?
episodes.longDescription: NDP MPP Cheri Dinovo and Liberal MPP, Marie-France Lalonde agree that the Corrections Act of Ontario is out-of-date.  Can a life-long champion of the downtrodden move the Minister to see what needs to be done to help those most at risk in our prisons?

episodes.title: Ep. 2 - Transit
episodes.shortDescription: Doug Ford and Jagmeet Singh take each other for a spin as they hit the road to debate an issue that has divided Torontonians for decades.
episodes.longDescription: Join Doug Ford and Jagmeet Singh as they try to navigate an issue that has divided Torontonians for decades. Whether to build subways, light rail, bike lanes - or all of the above - has been debated endlessly. Can a suburban road warrior and a champion of pedal power make peace?

episodes.title: Ep. 3 - Safe Injection Sites
episodes.shortDescription: As the opioid crisis explodes across the country, safe injection sites are being identified as an important way to help IV drug users survive. But where should they go?
episodes.longDescription: As the opioid crisis explodes across the country, safe injection sites are being identified as an important way to help IV drug users survive. But where should they go? London Mayor Matt Brown and Toronto City Councillor Giorgio Mammoliti take to the streets of London and Vancouver to see some of the worst drug-plagued neighbourhoods in North America.

series.shortDescription: In this six-part series, urban design expert Mikael Colville-Andersen explores the anatomy and vibrancy of the modern metropolis, highlighting pockets of life-sized goodness in cities around the world.
series.title: The Life-Sized City

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Barcelona
episodes.shortDescription: Spain's second-largest city is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Europe, with around 30 million tourists visiting Barcelona each year.
episodes.longDescription: Spain's second-largest city is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Europe, with around 30 million tourists visiting Barcelona each year. Given the city's small population of roughly 1.5 million citizens, however, the impact of tourism is significant and not all positive. Barcelona's rise in popularity has compelled locals to find solutions to reclaim their city, and make it more liveable.

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Beirut
episodes.shortDescription: Once considered the Paris of the Middle East, the ancient city of Beirut has survived brutal civil war, ongoing conflicts with Israel, political assassinations and endless bombings.
episodes.longDescription: Once considered the Paris of the Middle East, the ancient city of Beirut has survived brutal civil war, ongoing conflicts with Israel, political assassinations and endless bombings. Amidst crumbling buildings, a major garbage disposal crisis and frequent black outs, Beirutis take everything in stride, because they understand better than most that nothing gets done unless you do it yourself.

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Buenos Aires
episodes.shortDescription: Despite Argentina's history of political and economic upheaval, the nation's capital Buenos Aires has remained relatively stable.
episodes.longDescription: Despite Argentina's history of political and economic upheaval, the nation's capital Buenos Aires has remained relatively stable. But with millions moving to the city for a better life, the cracks in infrastructure and gaping income inequality are now overwhelming. In order to stem the tide, passionate locals have adopted a grassroots approach to tackling challenges big and small in order to ensure quality of life for all.

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Hamilton
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto has always cast a long shadow on the city of Hamilton, Ontario, for a number of reasons: it's bigger, it's more economically successful, and people want to live there. But times are changing.
episodes.longDescription: Toronto has always cast a long shadow on the city of Hamilton, Ontario, for a number of reasons: it's bigger, it's more economically successful, and people want to live there. But times are changing. Young people seeking opportunities are priced out of T.O., and Hamilton is proving to be the place that can provide them with both affordable housing as well as opportunity. Hamiltonians want us to know that great things come in mid-sized packages, too.

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Taipei
episodes.shortDescription: The capital of Taiwan is a young city undergoing rapid change and development within a fragile governmental framework.
episodes.longDescription: The capital of Taiwan is a young city undergoing rapid change and development within a fragile governmental framework. While the island boasts one of the highest economic growth rates in Asia, it maintains a tenuous relationship with China that makes its future uncertain. Fortunately, the citizens of Taipei are loud enough for the entire country, and they will do what it takes to make their voices heard in order to move forward into a more transparent, greener future.

episodes.title: Ep. 5 - Tel-Aviv
episodes.shortDescription: Few modern cities evoke as much division as Tel Aviv, with its reputation as a laid-back party town in a hotbed of conflict and turmoil.
episodes.longDescription: Few modern cities evoke as much division as Tel Aviv, with its reputation as a laid-back and permissive party town in a hotbed of conflict and turmoil. The problems of a rising cost of living, deficient public transport, and development conflicts are often put aside in the face of cyclical religious and cultural struggles that have marked its complex history. But people from both sides of the political and cultural divide are working together to create a more functional and united city.

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Toronto
episodes.shortDescription: Toronto has become a prominent cultural and artistic hub and a haven for foodies. Toronto is the big bity that doesn't feel impersonal. With 239 neighborhoods and people coming from all over the world, it's a multi-faceted and profoundly diverse city
episodes.longDescription: Toronto has become a prominent cultural and artistic hub and a haven for foodies. Toronto is the big bity that doesn't feel impersonal. With 239 neighborhoods and people coming from all over the world, it's a multi-faceted and profoundly diverse city.

episodes.title: Ep. 3 - Paris
episodes.shortDescription: Beyond the clichés of the Eiffel Tower, there is another Paris - one of solidarity, wittiness, and repurposing public space.
episodes.longDescription: Often perceived as cold and expensive, Paris is a mythical city, one of luxury, gastronomy and haute couture. But beyond the clichés of the Eiffel Tower, there is another Paris - one of solidarity, wittiness, and repurposing public space. This Paris revolves around change, inspiring solutions big and small to improve everyday life for its citizens. It hopes to minimize traffic, give a new life to the banks of the Seine River, and provide adequate lodging and a sense of belonging.

episodes.title: Ep. 6 - Tokyo
episodes.shortDescription: Modern Tokyo is a fascinating urban mystery. The largest agglomeration in the world, it is home to 38 million people.
episodes.longDescription: Modern Tokyo is a fascinating urban mystery. The largest agglomeration in the world, it is home to 38 million people. The entire population of Canada, in one city. On the surface, Tokyo feels like an oversized, man-built environment, made of endless rows of towers, glittering neons and fast-moving people. But this megacity, if you dig deeper, is much more than just impressive size.

episodes.title: The Life-Sized City - Medellin
episodes.shortDescription: A rose among the thorns in South American cities, few places have been so successful in tackling social problems head on with urbanism, architecture and greening of the urban landscape.
episodes.longDescription: A rose among the thorns in South American cities, few places have been so successful in tackling social problems head on with urbanism, architecture and greening of the urban landscape. There are few places like Medellin - from drug cartel hovel to urbanist dream. The work is no where near done but Medellin can inspire every other city in the world with it's visionary political and social choice and a strong network of urban activists.

episodes.title: Ep. 4 - Bangkok
episodes.shortDescription: Chaotic mix of skyscrapers, street markets and hidden alleyways, Bangkok is a vibrant hub of life, buzzing pretty much day and night.
episodes.longDescription: Chaotic mix of skyscrapers, street markets and hidden alleyways, Bangkok is a vibrant hub of life, buzzing pretty much day and night. Considered ,The Capital of Gridlock,, the city's traffic is among the worst in the world. The city's future seems paralyzed by recurring political upheavals. But social instability hasn't undermined the locals' fierce will to better their city. They're fighting back. Not with violence, but with their creativity and ingenuity.

episodes.title: Ep. 3 - Copenhagen
episodes.shortDescription: Is Denmark's capital the ultimate life-sized city? Urban design expert Mikael Colville-Andersen explores his own city.
episodes.longDescription: For the past decade, Copenhagen has consistently ranked near the top in dozens of annual global livability surveys. Is Denmark's capital the ultimate life-sized city? Is this model scalable? Urban design expert Mikael Colville-Andersen explores his own city and meets the people working daily to make it live up to its reputation.

episodes.title: Ep. 6 - Montreal
episodes.shortDescription: Although Montreal could be described as half Paris, half Brooklyn, the most populated francophone city in North America has an identity all its own.
episodes.longDescription: Although Montreal could be described as half Paris, half Brooklyn - it is after all the most populated francophone city in North America - the city has an identity of its own. Made up of a peculiar mix of creative citizens, cobblestones and potholes, Montreal is not the biggest, nor the richest or boldest. But it's one of the best cities to live in, and it certainly is a happy underdog.

episodes.title: Ep. 4 - Milan
episodes.shortDescription: Once considered the bland financial capital of Italy, Milan is proving its capacity to redefine itself as a multicultural hub.
episodes.longDescription: Once considered the bland financial capital of Italy, Milan is proving its capacity to redefine itself. An industrial past had left almost indelible scars on the urban fabric. But Expo 2015 sparked change: skyscrapers, new public and private initiatives, and innumerable urban renewal projects have since popped up on every block. Decades of open-mindedness, and of open doors to immigration, have made Milan the most multicultural hub in all of Italy.

episodes.title: Ep. 2 - Mexico City
episodes.shortDescription: Mexico City is the largest city in the Western hemisphere but many still see this megalopolis as a village - or as a patchwork of many villages.
episodes.longDescription: Mexico City, the largest city in the Western hemisphere, faces challenges ranging from social and economic inequity to environmental issues to its vulnerability to earthquakes. But many still see this megalopolis as a village - or as a patchwork of many villages, each preserving its own identity, yet home to a unique urban solidarity.

episodes.title: Ep. 1 - Cape Town
episodes.shortDescription: South Africa's Cape Town makes headlines for its beauty and laidback lifestyle, but traces of a dark past still linger.
episodes.longDescription: On the southwest coast of South Africa, Cape Town makes headlines for its laidback lifestyle and natural beauty. But beneath the sales pitch, traces of a dark past still linger. Amid de facto segregation and violence can also be found bold attempts at unity, and a city striving to use urban projects to create democratic inclusivity.

episodes.title: Ep. 5 - Detroit and Windsor
episodes.shortDescription: The southwestern Ontario city of Windsor has always lived in the shadow of its big American neighbour, Detroit, only 3.6 kilometres away.
episodes.longDescription: The southwestern Ontario city of Windsor has always lived in the shadow of its big American neighbour, Detroit, only 3.6 kilometres away. People cross the border every day for work or leisure. In a matter of decades, Detroit went from one of the most prosperous U.S. cities to one of the most distressed, culminating in the municipality's bankruptcy in 2013. How has this affected Windsor, a city trying to make a name of its own in Canada?

episodes.title: Blast Off
episodes.shortDescription: Ten promises to take the others on a trip to the moon.
episodes.longDescription: Ten promises to take the others on a trip to the moon but blasts off on her own. How will they get there? Find out which pairs of numbers add to make ten with the Numberblocks..

episodes.title: Ten Green Bottles
episodes.shortDescription: One of the bottles in Ten's collection accidentally falls off the wall.
episodes.longDescription: One of the bottles in Ten's collection accidentally falls off the wall, setting off a spectacular numbery hullabaloo. Learn to count down from ten by taking one away with the Numberblocks.

episodes.title: Just Add One
episodes.shortDescription: Learn to count to 10 by adding one with the Numberblocks.
episodes.longDescription: One's idea of fun is singing, dancing and making friends by adding One! Learn to count to 10 by adding one with the Numberblocks.

series.shortDescription: A five part HD series of international scope, consisting entirely of archival images. This historical project will bring a fuller awareness of the horrors of the war, and provide a better understanding of the reasons and outcomes.
series.title: Apocalypse: World War I

episodes.title: Ep. 4 - Rage
episodes.shortDescription: It's 1917 and people have had enough of the war. Behind the scenes, uprisings are brewing, like the one that toppled the Tsar in Russia; on the front soldiers begin to mutiny as they did at Chemin des Dames in France.
episodes.longDescription: It's 1917 and people have had enough of the war. Behind the scenes, uprisings are brewing, like the one that toppled the Tsar in Russia; on the front soldiers begin to mutiny as they did at Chemin des Dames in France. German submarine attacks in the Atlantic will finally pull the Americans into the war, but they arrive too late to help prevent the carnage of the Battle of Passchendaele.

episodes.title: Ep. 3 - Hell
episodes.shortDescription: The war is raging in Europe and stretches from the trenches in France to the Italian Alps and the Balkans, and beyond to the gates of the Eastern world.
episodes.longDescription: In 1916 the war is raging in Europe and stretches from the trenches in France to the Italian Alps and the Balkans, and beyond to the gates of the Eastern world. The conflict becomes industrial, and millions of shells rain down on the battlefields; Verdun and the Somme are the deadliest battles in this second year of the war. Who can stop this infernal machine?

episodes.title: Ep. 1 - Fury
episodes.shortDescription: On June 28, 1914, an obscure Austrian archduke's assassination in Sarajevo triggers a disastrous conflict.
episodes.longDescription: On June 28, 1914, the assassination of an obscure Austrian archduke in Sarajevo triggers the most disastrous conflict the world has ever known. Germany becomes an enemy to France, invades Belgium, and in September arrives at the gates of Paris. Will Germany win the war so quickly?

series.shortDescription: Two young eco-adventurer brothers, Alex and Tyler Mifflin, travel the world to explore our relationship with water. What are the problems and where will the solutions come from? The next generation takes us on the search.
series.title: The Water Brothers

episodes.title: Dead Zones
episodes.shortDescription: While it sounds more like a futuristic, sci-fi title, "Dead Zones" exist in our water environments and are rapidly increasing
episodes.longDescription: While it sounds more like a futuristic, sci-fi title, "Dead Zones" exist in our water environments and are rapidly increasing. Why? A Dead Zone is a term used to describe a greatly reduced level of oxygen in water, which often causes marine life to die. Excess nutrients that run off land into nearby water habitats stimulate an overgrowth of algae that in turn decomposes and depletes the oxygen in water. Habitats that were once teeming with life are reduced to biological deserts.

episodes.title: Here Comes the Flood
episodes.shortDescription: The brothers continue their journey down the sacred Ganges and head out to the lush Ganges Delta in Bangladesh to learn how the largest river delta in the world is both incredibly productive and the most vulnerable region to climate change.
episodes.longDescription: The brothers continue their journey down the sacred Ganges and head out to the lush Ganges Delta in Bangladesh to learn how the largest river delta in the world is both incredibly productive and the most vulnerable region to climate change.

episodes.title: The Pure and the Poisoned
episodes.shortDescription: For Hindus, nothing is more holy than the Ganges and this one river has a fascinating and central role in many of India's diverse cultures and religious traditions.
episodes.longDescription: For Hindus, nothing is more holy than the Ganges and this one river has a fascinating and central role in many of India's diverse cultures and religious traditions. Each stop along the river, from Kanpur to Varanasi, will teach us something new about how the ideas of religion, human population and pollution intersect, all in the context of water.

episodes.title: No Woman, No Water
episodes.shortDescription: The Water Brothers travel to eastern Africa, to the most water-scarce regions of Tanzania and Kenya, to see how simple water projects can make huge changes towards economic advancement.
episodes.longDescription: The United Nations has declared access to clean water and sanitation are human rights, knowing they are at the heart of any economic development. Yet hundreds of millions of people live without access to clean water and billions live without a toilet, causing countless lives to be lost each day. Women and girls are usually given the difficult task of hauling water, taking many hours each day often in the hot sun and sacrificing much for their families and communities. The Water Brothers travel to eastern Africa, to the most water-scarce regions of Tanzania and Kenya, to see how simple water projects can make huge changes towards economic advancement. It is women who are initiating these projects and often hold the key to improving clean water and sanitation access in their communities.

episodes.title: Plastic Ocean
episodes.shortDescription: The brothers embark on a sailing adventure to the middle of the Pacific Ocean with no land in sight in any direction for over 1,500 kilometers.
episodes.longDescription: The brothers embark on a sailing adventure to the middle of the Pacific Ocean with no land in sight in any direction for over 1,500 kilometers. They have joined a group of scientists and water advocates in the Marshall Islands in the South Pacific and travel together to the remote Great Pacific Garbage Patch - a massive collection of plastic waste congregated together by swirling ocean currents known as gyres.

episodes.title: Water Everywhere, but Not a Drop to Drink
episodes.shortDescription: In one of the most water rich countries in the world, approximately one out of every five First Nations communities in Canada lacks access to clean, safe and sustainable drinking water.
episodes.longDescription: Canadians are big water users and are also advanced in water storage, distribution, filtering and cleaning technologies, both domestically and for international use. Yet, in one of the most water rich countries in the world, approximately one out of every five First Nations communities in Canada lacks access to clean, safe and sustainable drinking water. Why do some communities have these problems and others do not? How can there be economic independence and advancement for our native communities without this basic human right?

episodes.title: Farmed and Dangerous?
episodes.shortDescription: The Brothers travel to British Columbia, home to the world's greatest wild salmon habitat and the heart of Canada's salmon farming industry.
episodes.longDescription: People love to eat salmon, but chances are that salmon is not wild. Over 70 per cent of the salmon eaten globally is raised on fish farms, some in ocean pens and some on land. The Water Brothers travel to British Columbia, home to the world's greatest wild salmon habitat and the heart of Canada's salmon farming industry. Wild salmon stocks are declining all along Canada's West Coast and many scientists believe that the use of open net farms in the Pacific Ocean, raising Atlantic salmon, could be inadvertently infecting wild Pacific salmon. Ironically, the salmon farms that are supposed to take the pressure off wild salmon stocks might be destroying them.

episodes.title: Reefer Madness
episodes.shortDescription: The world's coral reefs are home to a quarter of all marine life - and they're being wiped out. The Water Brothers visit the Meso-American reef, which stretches for over 1,000 km off the coasts of Mexico, Belize, Guatemala and Honduras.
episodes.longDescription: The world's coral reefs are home to a quarter of all marine life - and they're being wiped out. The Water Brothers visit the Meso-American reef, which stretches for over 1,000 km off the coasts of Mexico, Belize, Guatemala and Honduras. This reef attracts an incredible diversity of life, however, 80% of the coral cover across the entire Caribbean has disappeared in the last 30 years. Why is this happening and what can be done to end the destruction? The Water Brothers are determined to find out how both locals and tourists can play important roles in protecting reefs all around the world.

episodes.title: Bottlegate
episodes.shortDescription: Canadians enjoy one of the cleanest and most plentiful supplies of freshwater in the world. Tap water is also cheap and easily accessible, so why is there such a huge demand for bottled water?
episodes.longDescription: Canadians enjoy one of the cleanest and most plentiful supplies of freshwater in the world. Tap water is also cheap and easily accessible, so why is there such a huge demand for bottled water? The Water Brothers visit a water treatment facility and discover that water from the tap is often of the same quality or even better than bottled water. Globally, 17 million barrels of oil are needed to produce and distribute bottled water annually. The true cost of bottled water just doesn't add up, both in Canada and around the world.

episodes.title: Carpageddon
episodes.shortDescription: Asian carp have invaded the Mississippi River, and destroyed its lucrative fishing industry. Today, only an electric fence is keeping them from entering the Great Lakes, and a few have already been spotted.
episodes.longDescription: Asian carp have invaded the Mississippi River, and destroyed its lucrative fishing industry. Today, only an electric fence is keeping them from entering the Great Lakes, and a few have already been spotted. If any more cross that barrier, prepare for Carpageddon. The Water Brothers find out what an Asian carp invasion could do to the Great Lakes' 4.5 billion dollar fishing economy and examine how other invasive species like zebra mussels have changed the Great Lakes ecosystem.

episodes.title: The Big Thaw
episodes.shortDescription: The North Pole is melting faster than ever and the Northwest Passage could soon be an international shipping lane.
episodes.longDescription: The North Pole is melting faster than ever and the Northwest Passage could soon be an international shipping lane. Change in the Arctic is happening at warp speed, creating serious problems for the people and animals who live there. With rising sea levels, the fate of the world depends on slowing the Big Thaw. The Water Brothers visit the Arctic to get the facts and find answers.

episodes.title: Water in All the Wrong Places
episodes.shortDescription: California is naturally one of the driest places in North America, but how did it become the largest agricultural supplier on the continent?
episodes.longDescription: California is naturally one of the driest places in North America, but how did it become the largest agricultural supplier on the continent? A mind boggling system of dams, reservoirs and diversion schemes move water around vast distances, even from outside the State. The Water Brothers reveal how climate change, drought, flooding and over-pumped aquifers have combined to put the entire water management system at risk. And like in many other regions with water in all the wrong places, the pressure is always on to find clever and sustainable solutions.

episodes.title: Valley of the Dammed
episodes.shortDescription: For thousands of years, the culture and people of Southeast Asia have been shaped by the flow of the Mekong River.
episodes.longDescription: For thousands of years, the culture and people of Southeast Asia have been shaped by the flow of the Mekong River. However, the Mekong is undergoing incredible changes as a combination of climate change, overfishing and dams on Mekong tributaries have caused fish populations to plummet and altered water quality. The Water Brothers travel up the Mekong to learn how its conditions are changing and how a series of 11 planned mega-dams will further affect the river and its people.

episodes.title: The Water Brothers - Ocean Spies
episodes.shortDescription: For much of human history it has been nearly impossible to monitor the vast ocean but recent advancements in robot, drone and satellite technology are allowing humans to monitor the ocean and protect its wildlife like never before
episodes.longDescription: For much of human history it has been nearly impossible to monitor the vast ocean but recent advancements in robot, drone and satellite technology are allowing humans to monitor the ocean and protect its wildlife like never before

episodes.title: The Water Brothers - Flying Rivers
episodes.shortDescription: The Brothers travel to the Amazon to bring home the powerful message of what happens to the water cycle when too many trees are removed, and meet with innovative farmers and indigenous communities who are trying to protect forests while maintaining h
episodes.longDescription: The Brothers travel to the Amazon to bring home the powerful message of what happens to the water cycle when too many trees are removed, and meet with innovative farmers and indigenous communities who are trying to protect forests while maintaining high productivity and combating the growing threat of forest fires.

episodes.title: The Water Brothers - The Big Leak
episodes.shortDescription: Most of us enjoy fresh clean tap water 24/7, but few of us are aware of the complex network of pipes and sewage networks that bring us that water and take away our waste.
episodes.longDescription: Most of us enjoy fresh clean tap water 24/7, but few of us are aware of the complex network of pipes and sewage networks that bring us that water and take away our waste. Even fewer of us are aware of the severe problems facing these outdated water networks in major cities around the world.

episodes.title: The Water Brothers - On Thin Ice
episodes.shortDescription: Canada is home to over 1 million lakes and one of the largest freshwater supplies in the entire world, but scientists are discovering that these vast freshwater resources, and the ecosystems they support, are increasingly at risk.
episodes.longDescription: Canada is home to over 1 million lakes and one of the largest freshwater supplies in the entire world, but scientists are discovering that these vast freshwater resources, and the ecosystems they support, are increasingly at risk due to the effects of climate change. From changing rainfall patterns, to reduced snowpack, melting mountain glaciers and warming lakes, Canada is more vulnerable to climate change than many of us assume

episodes.title: The Water Brothers - More Food, Less Water
episodes.shortDescription: An astounding 70% of all the freshwater humans use is for agriculture. We need to use that water much more efficiently and the good news is that there are amazing new technologies being tested and implemented to help us grow more food with less water
episodes.longDescription: An astounding 70% of all the freshwater humans use is for agriculture. We need to use that water much more efficiently and the good news is that there are amazing new technologies being tested and implemented, some in our own backyard, to help us grow MORE FOOD and use LESS WATER.

episodes.title: The Water Brothers - The End of Sushi
episodes.shortDescription: Sushi has evolved from being a niche, exotic cuisine into one of the most popular foods in the world. The Brothers travel across North America to investigate the impact of this cuisine on health of the ocean.
episodes.longDescription: Sushi has evolved from being a niche, exotic cuisine into one of the most popular foods in the world. The Brothers travel across North America to investigate the impact of this cuisine on health of the ocean and meet sushi chefs who are introducing customers to more sustainable seafood options

series.shortDescription: This short video series visits big cities and small towns across Ontario revealing what makes each place unique. Step inside iconic community landmarks and meet the people who breathe life into local culture.
series.title: Main Street Ontario

episodes.title: Main Street Ontario: St. Catharines
episodes.shortDescription: The St. Catharines Standard was at the forefront of breaking news in the golden age of newspapers. Run by four generations of the Burgoyne family, The Standard's intrepid reporters delivered hard-hitting news and exposed environmental injustices.
episodes.longDescription: The St. Catharines Standard was at the forefront of breaking news during the golden age of newspapers. Run by four generations of the Burgoyne family, The Standard's intrepid reporters delivered hard-hitting journalism and exposed environmental injustices.  But times changed, and media consolidation hit the paper hard.

episodes.title: Main Street Ontario: Picton
episodes.shortDescription: Many childhood memories were made at The Regent Theatre when it first opened in 1918.  Although it has undergone many changes over the years, the community has rallied to keep these theatre doors open in downtown Picton, Ontario.
episodes.longDescription: Many childhood memories were made at The Regent Theatre when it first opened in 1918.  Although it has undergone many changes over the years, the community has rallied to keep these theatre doors open in downtown Picton, Ontario.

series.shortDescription: Northern Gold is a two-part series that uncovers the history of the northern Ontario city of Timmins.
series.title: Northern Gold

episodes.title: Ep 2 - After the Rush
episodes.shortDescription: As the city of Timmins grew, miners fought successfully to improve their working conditions.  Today, the city faces an uncertain future as mines close down.
episodes.longDescription: As the city of Timmins grew, miners fought successfully to improve their working conditions.  Today, the city faces an uncertain future as mines close down.  Multi-generational mining families like the Turcottes continue to work below ground - mining is in their blood.  As the city evolves, local Indigenous communities are embracing new possibilities with hope and resilience.  Coarse Language.

episodes.title: Ep 1 - A Fortune Found
episodes.shortDescription: Drawn to the area's newly discovered gold deposits, the immigrants that helped found the city of Timmins faced immense discrimination. As miners continued to work in hazardous conditions, northern Ontario gold fueled the economic boom in the south.
episodes.longDescription: Drawn to the area's newly discovered gold deposits, the immigrants that helped found the city of Timmins, Ontario faced immense prejudice and discrimination.  This treatment led to the controversial practice of highgrading during the Golden Age of mining in the 1920s-40s.  As miners continued to work in hazardous conditions, northern Ontario gold fueled the economic boom in the south.  Coarse Language.

series.shortDescription: The Great War comes to an end after four years of fierce fighting, and the survivors become aware that the world of the past century has disappeared.
series.title: Apocalypse: Never Ending War

episodes.title: Apocalypse: Never Ending War, Part 1
episodes.shortDescription: 1918. The Great War comes to an end after four years of fierce fighting. At the end of this 'total war' those who've survived become aware that the world of the past century has disappeared into an abyss of suffering.
episodes.longDescription: 1918. The Great War comes to an end after four years of fierce fighting. At the end of this 'total war' those who've survived become aware that the world of the past century has disappeared into an abyss of suffering.

tvSpecials.title: Care Rationing During a Pandemic
tvSpecials.shortDescription: How does Ontario's triage protocol for the pandemic affect elderly and disabled people.
tvSpecials.longDescription: Hospital triage protocols are fairly well-known - the person most in need receives the most immediate care. But what happens in a crisis such as a pandemic? Who decides care priorities when it comes to elderly people and those with disabilities? And are those priorities fair? Ontario Hubs editor Sarah Trick has been looking into how Ontario is handling this bioethics issue to create a policy in the event that hospitals become overwhelmed.
